title: 103_s1860
content: The Act is titled the "1995 Special Olympics World Games Commemorative Coin Act" and specifies the coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue 800,000 $1 silver coins for the 1995 Special Olympics World Games. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The design will feature the event's emblem, with inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "1995", and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". These coins will be legal tender as per US Code. Coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items for purposes of section 5132(a)(1) of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be selected after consultation with the 1995 Special Olympics World Games Organizing Committee, Inc. and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS. The coins authorized under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single Mint facility, starting no later than January 15, 1995, with a sunset provision ending minting after December 31, 1995. SEC. 6. SALE OF THE COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount. A surcharge of $10 per coin is required for all sales. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods/services for this Act. Compliance with equal employment laws is still required. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Secretary will promptly pay surcharges collected from coin sales to the 1995 Special Olympics World Games Organizing Committee, Inc. The funds will be used for the event, showcasing talents of individuals with mental retardation, and covering event costs. SEC. 9. AUDITS. The Comptroller General can audit the Committee's financial records. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no cost to the Government for issuing coins and require full payment, security, or guarantee for indemnification.
